questions.text: A female comes with unilateral lesions as shown in the image. She also has leukotrichia. The diagnosis is likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Segmental vitiligo The given image shows unilateral, localized depigmented macules. This feature and history of leukotrichia suggest a diagnosis of segmental vitiligo.

Highyeild:

Vitiligo Onset: Acquired disorder Pathogenesis: Autoimmune (most common)- Autoantibodies destroy melanocytes Triggers: Injury, illness, emotional stress, pregnancy Features: Chalky white depigmented macules Scalloped margin Leukotrichia Koebner’s phenomenon: Similar new lesions at site of trauma No sign of inflammation Diagnosis: Clinical Depigmented macules and patches that fluoresce under Wood lamp examination Treatment: <20% BSA involved >20% BSA involved - Topical steroids - Topical tacrolimus -Narrowband phototherapy -Systemic steroids -Azathioprine

questions.text: A child presented with itchy plaques over the neck, and bilateral popliteal and cubital fossa. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis The given clinical features and the image suggests the diagnosis of ‘atopic dermatitis'. It is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state. It is associated with a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema. The cardinal symptom is itching along with a Atopic dermatitis: It is classified as an endogenous eczema triggered by exogenous agents.

Highyeild:

ATOPIC DERMATITIS Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : periorbital, perioral and perinasal area are spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis :It is a chronic, intensely pruritic skin condition associated with gluten-sensitive.It typically occurs over extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. Option C. Pemphigus vegetans: It is a rare form of the bullous disorder that presents with large, moist, verrucous, vegetating plaques studded with pustules on the groin, axillae, and flexural surfaces. Option D. Psoriasis: It is a chronic T-cell mediated inflammatory disease that presents with well demarcated, erythematous, scaly plaques on the extensor surfaces of the body and scalp

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions as shown. The diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Borderline leprosy The given image shows hypopigmented plaques with annular ‘Swiss cheese’ inverted saucer or punched out appearanc e indicating borderline leprosy . Mid borderline leprosy It is the most unstable form of leprosy It can upgrade or downgrade either to borderline tuberculoid or borderline lepromatous depending on the immune status of the patient. Skin lesion: Polymorphic: Geographic map-like appearance Inverter saucer shape lesion: Inner punched out (Swiss cheese appearance) and sloping outwards. Histopathology Tuberculoid granulomas are less prominent Grenz zone is more prominent Transverse section of the nerve shows cut onion appearance

Lepromatous leprosy: Symmetrical skin lesions with very prominent grenz zone. Option D . Histoid leprosy: It is characterized by the formation of large, nodular, and sometimes infiltrative lesions on the skin, peripheral nerves, and other organs. The nodules are usually painless and have a firm, rubbery consistency, and can vary in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters.

questions.text: A child comes with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling on the scalp as shown. The next best step is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

KOH mount The given image shows a well-demarcated scaly patch in which hair shafts are broken off just above the skin resulting in alopecia indicating tinea capitis . KOH mount is useful for this condition

Highyeild:

KOH mount Scrapings are taken from the edge of the lesion and transferred to a slide KOH is added and examined under the microscope for the presence of hyphae. Potassium hydroxide preparation is one of the most commonly used direct fungal stains. Specimens are usually mounted in 10–30% potassium hydroxide ; the higher the percentage, the faster the specimen will clear. Treatment of skin scrapings, nails, or hairs with potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount dissolves tissue material while leaving the alkali-resistant fungi intact and aids in diagnosing mycoses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Other options: Option B . Gram staining: It is used to differentiate bacterial species based on the structure of their cell walls and can be used for the diagnosis of bacterial infections. Option C. Biopsy : It may be necessary if the diagnosis is unclear or if the condition is not responding to treatment. However, a biopsy is not typically the first diagnostic step in cases of suspected fungal infections. Option D . Slit skin smear: this is a technique used to detect the presence of microorganisms in the skin by obtaining a small sample of tissue or fluid from the affected area and examining it under a microscope. Slit skin smear is used primarily for the diagnosis of leprosy and other mycobacterial infections

questions.text: A patient comes with painful vesicles on their genitals. The histopathology finding will show

options.label: D
options.text: Cells with a clear halo around the nucleus

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tzanck cells The given image shows a cluster of vesicles on erythematous base suggesting genital herpes. On microscopy, Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cell s with Intranuclear inclusion bodies are seen when stained with Giemsa stain. The herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which break down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring.

Highyeild:

Herpes virus infection Virus - DNA Virus, multiply within the nucleus HSV-1 disease: Above diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis HSV-2 disease: Below diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Molluscum bodies are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum, a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. These bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies that are round or oval in shape, with a central clearing and are composed of viral particles. Option C. Henderson-Peterson bodies: Another name for molluscum bodies Option D. Cells with a clear halo around the nucleus: These may be indicative of viral infections, such as herpes simplex virus or varicella-zoster virus, but they are not specific to any particular virus or infection.

questions.text: The most specific and typical signs of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gottron’s papules Gottron’s papules are the typical and specific signs of juvenile dermatomyositis. These are violaceous (of violet color), lichenoid (red-purple), inflammatory, flat-topped papules on proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Highyeild:

Dermatomyositis Dermatomyositis (DM) is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterised by skeletal muscle weakness and skin changes. Genetic predisposition: PTPN22 gene and HLA associations Cutaneous Features: Heliotrope rash: Bilateral discolouration of the eyelids with swelling of eyelids and skin around the eyes. Shawl sign: Fixed redness affecting the back, shoulder and chest Photosensitivity: Sunreaction over the ‘V area’ Gottron Papules: Violaceous papules over the joints of hands Gottron sign: Redness over knees, elbows, knees Nailfold changes: Loss of cuticles/ragged cuticles with nail fold redness Nail fold dermoscopy: Shows dilated capillaries Calcinosis cutis Raynaud phenomenon Mechanic's hands : hyperkeratotic, cracked horizontal lines on the palmar and lateral aspects of the fingers. Flagellate erythema : characterised by multiple, red, macular streaks occurring on the trunk and proximal limbs. The stripes are aligned diagonally giving the appearance of whipping. Myositis of dermatomyositis Muscle weakness appears at the same time as the skin rash It usually affects proximal muscles Muscle pain and tenderness may be present

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Photosensitivity: It can be seen in multiple conditions like SLE, dermatitis, migraine, dermatomyositis, Darier’s disease, etc. Option B. Nailfold capillaries: Nail fold capillary abnormalities are present in more than 95% of patients with systemic sclerosis. Nailfold capillary changes may be present in dermatomyositis but are not characteristic. Option C. Malar rash: It is aka butterfly rash, and is a common facial presentation of multiple disorders. It is characterized by erythematous flat photosensitive lesions.

questions.text: An adult male with a history of visiting forests recently developed the following lesion. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kyasanur forest disease The image shows black eschar, Kyasanur forest disease does not present with escha. Kyasanur forest disease Cause: KFD virus Symptoms: Presents with abrupt onset of fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and severe prostration. Some cases may develop hemorrhages in the skin, mucosa, and viscera

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Cutaneous Anthrax: Caused by Bacillus anthracis. Itwith black eschar which initially starts as a painless papule and progresses to form a malignant pustule forming an eschar. Since this is a zoonosis, there should be a history of handling infecting animals like sheep. Option C . Scrub typhus: Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by-Vector: Trombiculid mite. It presents with -Fever, headache, body aches, and rash. Black eschar: Black scab surrounded by erythema is seen at the bite site. Option D .Healing brown recluse of a spider bite- Can also present with a black Eschar.
